description:
Tableau is one of the leading visualization software products in the business world today. If you want to learn how to make engaging, interactive visualizations with a simple click and drag interface, join CDSS as we welcome Tableau expert Adam McCann for a workshop followed by a Q&A session.

Adam McCann is a Specialist Leader with Deloitte Consulting in their Analytics and Information Management group where he specializes in predictive analytics and data visualization. At Deloitte, he leads a team of consultants at a national intelligence agency developing predictive models and business intelligence solutions. Adam also teaches an information visualization course at Maryland Institute College of Art. His data visualization blog duelingdata.com covers topics ranging from movies, sports and politics. He is also 2015-2017 Tableau Zen Master, a title recognizing the top Tableau practitioners in the world for their mastery of the product.

As a Columbia student, you can download Tableau for free! Just follow the instructions at the link below. Please download Tableau prior to the workshop so you can follow along!

www.tableau.com/academic/students
title: Data Visualization with Tableau

description: Apache Spark is one of the most useful big data frameworks. Come learn how you can experiment it and harness it for large scale analytics! We’ll cover a conceptual introduction to Spark and the basics of the Python interface, PySpark.
title: Scalable Analytics with Spark

description:
So much of the information we encounter every day is hard to conceptualize. It’s so big and complicated that a visual rendering represents it the best. Being a good data designer is crucial to being able to tell the story behind the data.

Come push your data visualization techniques, processes, and methods to the next level with Juan Francisco Saldarriaga.

Juan Francisco Saldarriaga is a Mapping and Data Visualization Specialist, an Architectural Designer, and an Urban Planner living and working in New York. Juan Francisco has both a Masters of Science in Urban Planning and a Masters of Architecture from Columbia University. For his undergrad, Juan Francisco studied philosophy at the Université de Paris IV (Sorbonne) and at the Universidad de Los Andes, Bogotá.

Check some of his work: http://cargocollective.com/juanfrans/
title: Next Level Data Visualization with Juan Francisco

description:
What even is a data science interview? Do they want me to be a developer, or an analyst, or a unicorn? At this workshop we'll go over what to expect in data science interviews, focusing especially on in person tech interviews. From the basic layout to the right answer to (almost) every "what data structure can you use to make this faster" question, you'll be ready to land the internship or job of your data science filled dreams.

Chris Mulligan is currently a Quantitative Researcher at Two Sigma Investments, LP. He builds models to make predictions of financial markets using untraditional data, which is a sentence he never imagined he’d say about himself. Prior to Two Sigma Chris completed data science internships at Kickstarter, Facebook, and The New York Times, as well as 7 years in political data analysis and modeling, most recently as Director of Analytics at YouGov. Chris received BA and MA degrees in computer science and statistics from Columbia in 2015, where he was a TA for COMS3157 AP and STAT4400 StatML, and cofounded CDSS.
title: Hacking Data Science Interviews

description:
(This event is co-organized by Gamma Iota Sigma at Columbia "https://m.facebook.com/groups/342565339243399/".)

Mike Jaron, current QMSS student and Google Data Scientist, will give a talk about his day-to-day work, the culture of data science at Google, and his thoughts on the future trends regarding Data Science, followed by a Q&A session. 

Mike works on the Human/Social Dynamics program, where he specializes in natural language processing and data analysis in Python and R. Bring any questions you have about data science at Google, Mike's career, and anything in between!
title: Data Science at Google

description:
Let's talk about data science classes for Spring 2017! Not sure where to start? Did you crush Machine Learning and are looking for your next favorite class? Want to know about workload, group projects, and tests? We have you covered! Hope to see you there!

Please fill out the following form to submit topics and questions for the event. bit.ly/CULPAs17
title: CULPA Live: Ask Us Anything about Course Selection

group: EGSC - Engineering Graduate Student Council, Columbia University
description: This event will showcase the ongoing research in SEAS departments and highlight the achievements of the EGSC Professional Development Scholars. Labs with with open positions will describe the opportunities available for short- to long-term research assistantships. Masters student interested in research are particularly encouraged to attend! Refreshments will be served.
title: EGSC Research Symposium

group: EGSC - Engineering Graduate Student Council, Columbia University
description:
Too stressed from working on those long assignments and job applications? Take a break and unwind as EGSC takes you out for a Happy Hour at Bernheim and Schwartz (114th Street and Broadway) on a Friday night. Appetizers and beverages will be served. Ticket sales start on 11/12 at 12 noon.

Required:

- Eventbrite registration
- CUID with EP Sticker
- Government issued age proof ID
title: Happy Hour
location: Bernheim and Schwartz Restaurant & Beer Hall

group: EGSC - Engineering Graduate Student Council, Columbia University
description:
For many students, transitioning to graduate student life can be overwhelming. We, at EGSC, recognize the challenges that students face during this period and understand the impact they may have on an individual’s experience at Columbia Engineering. This mentorship program connects students with mentors who can help them navigate life as a graduate student.

Do you have no idea what classes to take? Did you read the course description and got even more confused? Well don't worry, you're not alone! 

As our first event of the semester, mentors of the EGSC Mentorship Program will be giving their advice to mentees regarding the upcoming course registration. This is intended to be a social get-together, to give students the opprtunity to receive advice from older students in their departments regarding their personal experiences and opinions on various courses in hopes of making the registration process a much easier one.

If you're interested in being a mentor or signing up as a mentee, please fill out the corresponding form below:

Mentor:https://docs.google.com/a/columbia.edu/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfi3uQOIpmIsW47WVcscIhgtKY38LHZHpLHTZ3UxIKK6kkbbw/viewform?c=0&w=1
Mentee: https://docs.google.com/a/columbia.edu/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeXZx9z98R1krEbdCJc6Rcf0dGHzE8IlZceGSHEf8fyjRHFFw/viewform?c=0&w=1

If you would like to know more about EGSC's Peer Mentoring Program, find out at http://egsc.seas.columbia.edu/mentors.html.
title: Course Registration With EGSC Peer Mentors

group: EGSC - Engineering Graduate Student Council, Columbia University
description:
The EGSC takes you on this exciting adventure with Doctor Strange. Join us!!  Tickets go on sale on 11/03 at 5 PM. Get yours soon!

Dr. Stephen Strange's (Benedict Cumberbatch) life changes after a car accident robs him of the use of his hands. When traditional medicine fails him, he looks for healing, and hope, in a mysterious enclave. He quickly learns that the enclave is at the front line of a battle against unseen dark forces bent on destroying reality. Before long, Strange is forced to choose between his life of fortune and status or leave it all behind to defend the world as the most powerful sorcerer in existence.

Ticket Price: $5 only. Limited Availability. 

CU ID with EP Sticker required.


The group will meet outside Carleton Commons and depart at 6.00 PM sharp.
title: EGSC Movie Night

description: Cathy O'Neil discusses her book, Weapons of Math Destruction, and the power of algorithms to destroy lives, increase inequality and threaten democracy.
title: Weapons of Math Destruction

description: Cathy O'Neill discusses her book Weapons of Math Destruction and the potential for algorithms to discriminate and threaten democracy.
title: Cathy O'Neill: Weapons of Math Destruction

description: Booz Allen Hamilton data scientists Ben Arancibia and Liebermann share stories from the trenches.
title: Applying Data Science to Real-World Problems

description:
StatFest 2016
Illuminating Statistics via Dashboard

Columbia Statistics Club is challenging you to create a Statistical Dashboard for general public use. In this competition you will be able to learn and apply new techniques through our tutorials:

-Dashboard Designing
-Communicating Statistics to General Public

This is a Stats.org and Columbia Statistics Club event.

All are welcome to join!

For more information, please contact us at our Facebook page:
@columbiastatisticsclub

You can sign up through Eventbrite's ticket URL.
title: StatFest 2016

description:
CORE, ADI, and Tau Beta Pi are proud to present a screening of "She Started It", a documentary that follows five passionate, trailblazing young women who strive to compete and thrive in the ruthlessly competitive boys’ club of high tech startups.

Through intimate, action-driven storytelling, She Started It explores the cultural roots of female underrepresentation in entrepreneurship—including pervasive self-doubt, fear of failure, and risk aversion among young women. It exposes, too, the structural realities women face as they become entrepreneurs, including lack of female role models and investors, and the persistent dearth of venture capital funding made available to women-led companies.

There will be popcorn!

**This event is open to the public! We ask that you register here if you are not a Columbia student so we can guarantee you have access to the screening location: https://coreatcu.wufoo.com/forms/she-started-it-film-screening-registration-form/

**More information about She Started It can be found here: http://www.shestarteditfilm.com/
title: She Started It: Film Screening

group: Medical Informatics Society at Columbia University
description:
The Columbia Medical Informatics Society, in collaboration with the Center for Career Education and GlobeMed, are hosting a panel and networking session for organizations with opportunities in Healthcare and Life Sciences Technology. This event is aimed to educate students about opportunities available in these industries and allow companies to meet enthusiastic and bright Columbia students. Our target audience is undergraduate students interested in summer internships and/or full-time opportunities. Attending this Industry Showcase will provide students the unique opportunity to meet professionals and other interested students in the field.

******This event is only open to Barnard and Columbia undergraduate students (BC, CC, GS, SEAS). Students interested in attending must register via LionShare: 
https://columbia.joinhandshake.com/career_fairs/1160 . Alumni are also welcome, and should contact Suzanne Cadden (sc4051@columbia.edu) to register.  

Event Format:
- Panel presentation: 6:00 PM – 6:45 PM
- Networking: 6:45 PM – 7:30 PM

Employers attending:
- athenahealth
- Medidata Solutions
- Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center: Strategy and Innovation team
- Phreesia
- Remedy Partners
- Riparian, LLC
- SolveBio
- Spreemo, Inc. 
- WebMD
title: Industry Showcase: Health Technology

group: Columbia University Graduate Student Advisory Council (GSAC)
description:
Need to drink the election results away?

Join GSAC for our November Night at the Bar.
We will be in the Private Speakeasy.

For $5 you can get unlimited Well Bar Drinks.
Tickets will NOT be on sale at the door.
Ticket sales close at 7:00pm 11/10/16


Drinks include:
Well Open Bar, Bottled Beer, Draft Beer, Wine, Soda and Juice (Premium/Top-Shelf Liquors, Pitchers and Shots Not Included)

One guest allowed per Columbia Student. 
Guest must be with Columbia student at entry.
Please have your Government (21+) ID and Student ID.
title: Post Election Night at the Bar - The Gin Mill at the Speakeasy

description: Join Columbia College Student Ambassadors for a night of Columbia-based trivia! Take a study break, show off your CU knowledge, and learn something new about interesting campus facts, famous alumni, the core, and all things Columbia. There will be free prizes, pizza, and dessert :) Come by for a great time!
title: CCSA Trivia Night
location: Furnald Hall, Columbia University Undergraduate Student Life

description:
"SIPA Diversity Spotlight Series: Navigating the Professional Policy World as a Person of Color"

Join alumni and current students from SIPA's Diversity Coalition - SIPA Students of Color, Gender Policy Working Group, Human Rights Working Group, and Spectrum - for a discussion over lunch on the importance of a diverse student body in schools of public policy and international affairs, and how to navigate the professional policy world as a person of color. 

*Lunch will be provided.

Registration is required. Please use the ticket link to confirm your attendance.

Note: This is a closed event for prospective students and applicants. Only members/alumni of the following groups are welcome to attend: SIPA Students of Color, Gender Policy Working Group, Human Rights Working Group, and Spectrum.
title: SIPA Diversity Spotlight Series: The Symposium

description: Come chill with our BME department's very own Dr. Hess, whose work is concerned with "engineering at the molecular scale, in particular the design of active nanosystems incorporating biomolecular motors, the study of active self-assembly, and the investigation of protein-resistant polymer coatings."  Ask him about anything from his career path to his go-to dinner spots.
title: Fun with Faculty: Dr. Hess!

description:
Join Senior Vice Dean, Soulaymane Kachani, to learn more about graduate engineering degree programs and admission requirements.

Room: Salle de Conference
title: Paris Information Session

description:
Please join us for a multilingual rosary vigil! This will be an incredibly meaningful time for reflection and prayer. It will also be a chance to learn more about your Columbia community. If you speak a second language and would like to participate, please let us know at gf2341@columbia.edu! 

WHEN: November 17th (in place of Holy Hour), 8-9:30 pm 
WHERE: Corpus Christi Church
title: Multilingual Rosary Vigil

description: Greetings! Are you interested in learning different partner dances (salsa, swing, etc.)?  Join us after Holy Hour at the gym for beginner lessons! If you have zero experience, this will be a great opportunity to learn with your friends.  If you have experience, bring some of your friends to learn!
title: Beginner Dance Lesson - Salsa

description:
Exhibition Models examines new curatorial practices, scholarship, and institutional experiments that are redefining the agency of architecture exhibitions.

Presentations and panels offer case-studies and consider the format, role, and impact of exhibitions in different settings ranging from academic venues, alternative spaces, and well-established institutions to project-based architecture biennials and triennials.

ILLUMINATIONS
This panel considers the role of exhibitions in academic institutions as both pedagogical resource and platform for groundbreaking new research.

Mark Wasiuta, Arthur Ross Architecture Gallery
Nina Stritzler-Levine, Bard Graduate Center
Andres Lepik, Architekturmuseum TU Munich
Vanessa Norwood, Architectural Association
Moderated by Reinhold Martin, Columbia GSAPP

CURATORIAL DISPATCHES I

U.S. Pavilion, 2016 Venice Biennale:
Cynthia Davidson and Mónica Ponce de León, curators
Oslo Architecture Triennale:
Lluís A. Casanovas, Ignacio G. Galán, Carlos Mínguez, Alejandra Navarrete, Marina Otero Verzier, After Belonging Agency, curators
Moderated Felicity Scott, Columbia GSAPP

INSTITUTIONAL COORDINATES
Innovative approaches to architecture exhibitions across scales: from independent experimental spaces to new strategies at established institutions.

Michael Govan, LACMA
Rory Hyde, V&A
Wonne Ickx, Isabel Martínez Abascal, LIGA DF
Fernando Portal, Mil M2
Moderated by Irene Sunwoo, Columbia GSAPP

CURATORIAL DISPATCHES II

Istanbul Biennial:
Beatriz Colomina and Mark Wigley, curators
Lisbon Architecture Triennale:
André Tavares, curator
Moderated by Mark Wasiuta, Columbia GSAPP

PANEL DISCUSSION

Beatrice Galilee, The Met
Joseph Grima, Ideas City, New Museum
Sarah Herda, Graham Foundation
Sylvia Lavin, UCLA, Architecture & Urban Design Moderated by Amale Andraos and Galia Solomonoff, Columbia GSAPP

Registration is recommended - please register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/exhibition-models-curating-architecture-tickets-27905213244

Organized by Columbia GSAPP
title: Exhibition Models: Curating Architecture

group: Columbia University South Asian Feminisms Alliance
description:
SAFA and STF are proud to present "Girl Rising," a documentary that follows nine passionate girls from developing countries who strive for equal educational opportunity. The film journeys around the globe to witness the strength of the human spirit and the power of education to change the world. We will discuss the film afterwards!

Bring your friends to destress during midterms and watch some good quality feminist film!
title: SAFA and STF's Film Screening: Girl Rising

description:
Join Culinary Society for our November event!  Make anything with the common ingrediant: cereal. If you don't cook, come out and enjoy eating a delicious array of foods. We hope to see you there!

If you want to cook for the event, sign up here! If you don't have a kitchen, please email us at culinarysocietycu@gmail.com.
https://docs.google.com/a/columbia.edu/spreadsheets/d/190VudP4BonLTeXha9WjOPFyZ47M5gEjZjbGUbkLMFpE/edit?usp=sharing
title: Culinary Society: Who's the ceREAL Top Chef

description: Join FLIP and CCE for an info session on all the resources CCE has available to First-generation and/or Low-Income students. Find out the best way to approach the job search and the best way to utilize all that CCE has to offer.
title: FLIP the Job Search

description:
Join us to learn more about Meetup's Women in Tech internship opportunities! Lunch will be provided. Feel free to bring your resume.

Meetup is a platform that connects people throughout the world to do more of the things they love to do. What comes from this is the building of communities and the discovery of new places and things through tech! This summer 2017, the Meetup Engineering team will bring on a community of 6 to 8 women engineers to learn, do, grow, and engineer through the Women in Tech Internship. Interns will be partnered with a mentor and will have the opportunity to join one of the following teams:

UI Engineering
Back-end Engineering
Mobile Engineering (iOS and Android)
Machine Learning/Data Engineering

Check out our 2016 Intern, Emily's summer with us:
https://medium.com/ladies-storm-hackathons/the-review-6eba506c8d9e#.r6xxb3ss6

See how Meetup's CTO Yvette is making a difference for more women in tech:
https://backchannel.com/how-meetup-ditched-its-boys-club-4a3a3084e72f#.158g7fejx
title: Meetup Women in Tech 2017

description:
The sisters of Kappa Alpha Theta - Epsilon Upsilon Chapter invite you to join us at our fall philanthropy event - CUPCAKES FϴR CASA!

Stop by our brownstone for some sweet treats. We will also have a photo booth and raffle prizes! All proceeds benefit the NYC chapter of our national philanthropy, National Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) Association.

Our annual Greek Bake Off will feature special cupcakes made by:

Alpha Epsilon Pi - Iota Chapter, Columbia University
Beta Theta Pi - Columbia University
Delta Sigma Phi
Kappa Delta Rho (Columbia University)
Phi Gamma Delta - Omega Chapter at Columbia University
Pi Kappa Alpha - PIKE - Columbia University
Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity at Columbia University
Sigma Chi Nu Nu
Sigma Lambda Beta
Sigma Phi Epsilon - Columbia University
Sigma Nu Fraternity

Reps from Columbia University Panhellenic sororities will judge the contest. 

You can buy tickets for $10 at the door or $7 in Lerner, 11/2-11/3, 11/9-11/10 11-6 PM. 

For more info on CASA, visit http://www.casa-nyc.org/
title: Kappa Alpha Theta presents Cupcakes FϴR CASA

description: Curious how to make an impression at a networking event or how to send that email for a coffee chat? Come to CIBD's second lecture about the art of networking. It will be a multiple choice style lecture covering the best ways to interact with recruiting teams.
title: CIBD Lecture--How to Network
